tossups.question: According to the Shimer puzzle, fluctuations in this quantity are much smaller than predicted by models. The Shapiro-Stiglitz model claims that efficient wages sustain this quantity, which is plotted against vacancy in the Beveridge Curve. A 1% increase in this quantity leads to a (*) 2% decrease in GDP according to Okun’s Law. The NAIRU model represents an improvement on Milton Friedman’s theory of a “natural” level of this quantity. This phenomenon is inversely related to inflation by the Phillips Curve and increases during a recession. For ten points, name this phenomenon where people who are willing to work can’t find jobs.

A red chair is visible in the bottom-left corner of a painting by this artist described as “The Jumping Off Place.” This artist of Rooms by the Sea depicted a man surveying an urban landscape their spouse described as “the man in the concrete wall. In another of this artist’s paintings, a fire hydrant and (*) barber pole cast tall shadows down an empty street. This painter of Office in a Small City and Early Sunday Morning painted two women sitting across from each other at a Chinese restaurant in Chop Suey. An ad for Phillies cigars can be seen in one painting by this man depicting three patrons of a diner. For ten points, name this painter of Nighthawks.

This author wrote about a traumatized car salesman turned disk jockey named Mucho and his wife, who are followed around by a band called the Paranoids. This author of the story collection Slow Learner wrote a novel in which the title stamps lead the protagonist to a syndicate symbolized by a muted posthorn, the Tristero. This author wrote another novel in which a group of characters seek an object labeled (*) 00000. This author wrote about Pierce Inverarity's coexecutor, Oedipa Maas, and in another novel, the sexual exploits of Tyrone Slothrop correlate with V-2 rocket strikes. For ten points, name this author of The Crying of Lot 49 and Gravity's Rainbow.

Failed negotiations during the Cripps Mission ordered by this leader exacerbated political tensions and food shortages in one country. This leader wrote the autobiography My Early Life during their “wilderness years,” and later was awarded a Nobel Prize in Literature after writing a History of the English-Speaking Peoples. This leader resigned as (*) First Lord of the Admiralty following the failure of the Gallipoli campaign in World War I. This leader described a barrier that stretched from “Stettin in the Baltic to Trieste in the Adriatic” in his “Iron Curtain” speech. For ten points, name this prime minister that led Britain in World War II.

This author describes a message that never reaches a subject “far from the imperial sun” due to infinite crowds in the excerpt of a story known as “A Message from the Emperor.” Another excerpt by this author features a dying man who learns that a gateway he is barred from entering was assigned only to him before it is permanently closed. This author featured that allegory, (*) “Before the Law,” in a story about a man killed “like a dog” in a ditch, Josef K. This author created a salesman killed by an apple thrown by his father. For ten points, name this German author of “The Trial” and a novella in which Gregor Samsa transforms into a bug, “The Metamorphosis.”

The presence of this substance is the most likely cause for a perceived offset in the center of mass of the Bullet Cluster. This substance was hypothesized to be self-interacting as a result of the core-cusp problem. A region in which this substance is gravitationally bound is called this substance’s (*) “halo.” Weakly interacting massive particles are one candidate for this substance. Most of this substance is thought to be “cold” instead of “warm” or “hot.” This substance gets its name because it does not interact with the electromagnetic force, and thus, is invisible. For ten points, name this substance which accounts for most of the matter in the universe.
tossups.answer: dark matter [do not accept or prompt on “matter” or “antimatter” or “dark energy”]
tossups.answer_formatted: dark matter [do not accept or prompt on "“matter”" or "“antimatter”" or "“dark energy”"]

tossups.question: According to legend, this person served colonel Robert Gould Shaw his last meal before he led an assault at Fort Wagner. This person guided James Montgomery and the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment in the military raid on Combahee Ferry. In 2016, Treasury Secretary Jack Lew announced that this activist would replace (*) Andrew Jackson on the twenty dollar bill. This abolitionist would use a series of secret routes and safe houses to help her lead passengers on the Underground Railroad. For ten points, name this suffragist known as “Moses” for her work guiding escaped slaves.

When ghrelin binds to GHS-R1a [G-H-S-R-one-A], a compound that induces this process is secreted. The second of two proteins named for their structural similarities to insulin primarily contributes to this process in fetuses. Somatostatin, a hormone released by pancreatic and intestinal delta cells, inhibits this process in humans. The primary hormone responsible for this process causes thickening of the jaw, fingers, and toes when present in excess amounts, called (*) acromegaly. This process is controlled by HGH in humans. For ten points, name this process that typically occurs in namesake “spurts” during puberty.
tossups.answer: physical growth [accept answers indicating an increase in size; accept specific kinds of growth; accept answers indicating that new cells are created; prompt on development]
tossups.answer_formatted: physical growth [accept answers indicating an increase in size; accept specific kinds of growth; accept answers indicating that new cells are created; prompt on development]
acceptable: answers indicating an increase in size
answers indicating that new cells are created

tossups.question: The Marasa Twins are a set of ancient divine beings in this religion. This religion considers the soul to be made up of two elements, known as the big good angel and the little good angel. In this religion, many features of the universe were created by the coils and skin of the snake deity Damballah. Male and female priests in this religion are known as Houngans and (*) Mambos, respectively. In this religion, deities like Papa Legba and Baron Samedi are known as loa, and are under the authority of the creator god Bondye. Despite popular belief, this religion does not usually involve sticking pins in dolls. For ten points, name this syncretic religion practiced by many in Haiti.

Samuel Butler argued that the author of this work was actually a woman from Sicily. In this work, the protagonist breaks into tears after a blind bard sings of his exploits. This work’s main character is found naked on a beach by the daughter of King Alcinous named (*) Nausicaa. The protagonist of this work is greeted after returning home by the swineherd Eumaeus and owns the faithful dog Argos. The wife of this work’s protagonist weaves and unweaves a burial shroud everyday to keep her suitors at bay, and is named Penelope. For ten points, name this Homerian epic about a hero’s return to Ithaca following the Trojan War.

One of this musician’s first songs features a long clarinet solo by Johnny Dodds and is noted for its use of stop-time; that recording is “Potato Head Blues.” This musician recorded the duet “Weather Bird” with the pianist Earl Hines. Ella Fitzgerald and this musician collaborated to record music from Porgy and Bess in 1959. On the song “Heebie Jeebies,” this musician first utilized his signature (*) scat singing style, and on a different song, this man describes “trees of green / red roses too.” For ten points, name this jazz trumpeter nicknamed “Satchmo” who sang “What a Wonderful World.”

In one episode of this show, a sarcasm-loving character stumbles into a haiku lesson. In that same episode, the father of the deceased Lu Ten tearfully sings the song "Leaves from the Vine." That character on this show was voiced by Mako Iwamatsu and is a tea-loving member of the secret White Lotus society. In addition to (*) Uncle Iroh, this show's hero is taught by a blind character who sees with seismic sense and a banished prince with a scar. This show features Toph Beifong and Zuko and centers on stopping Fire Lord Ozai's conquest of the Four Nations. For 10 points, name this Nickelodeon cartoon that follows Aang, a 12 year old boy who must master all four elements.
tossups.answer: Avatar: The Last Airbender [accept Avatar: The Legend of Aang; prompt on partial answers]
tossups.answer_formatted: Avatar: The Last Airbender [accept Avatar: The Legend of Aang; prompt on partial answers]

tossups.question: John Gerard created the first printed image of these objects, though he mistakenly stated they came from Virginia. Antoine-Augustin Parmentier was a notable advocate for these goods after they were banned by the French parliament. The War of Bavarian Succession was alternatively named for this good, and the Gregory Clause forced peasants to surrender their land in order to receive assistance during an event named for these objects. Thousands escaped in (*) coffin ships during one event named for this crop that led Robert Peel to repeal the Corn Laws. The Irish Great Famine occurred due to a shortage of, for ten points, what hearty root vegetable?
tossups.answer: potatoes [accept patates or pomme de terres, accept kartoffeln]

tossups.question: The Darcy–Weisbach equation relates this force to the loss of fluid pressure in a pipe. One form of this force is independent of velocity according to a non-electrical law named for Coulomb. This force separates electrical charges through the triboelectric effect. For an inclined plane, the angle of (*) repose is the largest angle at which this force prevents an object’s movement. Ball bearings are commonly used to reduce the effect of this force. The magnitude of this force is equal to the normal force times a namesake coefficient symbolized mu. For ten points, name this force that comes in “static” and “kinetic” types and opposes motion.
tossups.answer: friction [accept Darcy friction factor or static friction or kinetic friction]
tossups.answer_formatted: friction [accept Darcy friction factor or static friction or kinetic friction]

tossups.question: One of these creatures lives with Mr. Sneaze before drowning in a novella by Natsume Soseki. Johnnie Walker attempts to kill these creatures to create a flute out of their souls. An executioner struggles to behead the talking head of one of these creatures who appears on a croquet field owned by the Queen of (*) Hearts. In The Wind-up Bird Chronicle, Toru Okada searches for one of these animals, which often feature in the novels of Haruki Murakami. Dinah is one of these animals in a Lewis Carroll work, in which another of these creatures vanishes until only his smile remains. For ten points, what animal is described by the term “Cheshire” in Alice in Wonderland?
tossups.answer: cats [accept I Am A Cat, accept the Cheshire Cat]

tossups.question: A diminished seventh chord consists of four notes that are each this many semitones apart. A major chord that comes at the end of a piece in a minor key is named for Picardy and the ordinal form of this number. The mediant is the scale degree of this number. A dissonant interval composed of this many whole tones is frequently used to depict hell and is known as “the (*) devil in music.” Major chords differ from minor chords by the scale degree of this number, which is the number of beats per measure in a waltz. The major interval of this number is enharmonic to a diminished fourth. For ten points, identify the number of whole tones in a tritone.
tossups.answer: three [accept third or tritone before mention; accept Picardy third]

tossups.question: The leaves of this plant are used as food wrappings in an Indonesian cooking technique known as pepes. In Puerto Rican cuisine, this food is sliced and fried twice to make tostones. Traditional Indian meals are served on the leaves of this plant, whose “Gros (*) Michel” variety was wiped out by disease in the 1950s. Chiquita is a common producer of this foodstuff, which are considered to be good sources of potassium. In Colombian cuisine, this food is fried and combined with beef broth and vegetables in a plantain soup. For ten points, what fruit is cut in half in an ice-cream based dessert known as its namesake “split?”

A derivative of this compound and acetone are produced from the oxidation of an isopropyl version of this compound via the cumene process. Three nitro groups are added to another derivative of this compound to create an explosive material. Substituents are added onto this compound in a Friedel-Crafts reaction. Adding a hydroxyl group to this molecule gives (*) phenol, while adding a methyl group gives toluene. The structure of this molecule was formulated by August Kekule, and is drawn using either alternating single and double bonds or a circle inside a ring. For ten points, name this simplest aromatic compound with formula C6H6 [C-six-H-six].
tossups.answer: benzene [or cyclohexa-1,3,5-triene or 1,3,5-cyclohexatriene; accept C6H6 [C-six-H-six] until it is mentioned; prompt on phenol or toluene until it is mentioned with “what simpler compound is that derived from?”]

tossups.question: The Hørdum Stone depicts an attempt to capture one of these creatures. Another one of these creatures gnaws at the roots of Yggdrasil from its residence of Hvergelmir and is named Nidhoggr. One god was unable to lift a grey cat that turned out to be one of these creatures, which he will kill at (*) Ragnarok before walking nine steps then dying from poison. Hymir stopped Thor from capturing one of these creatures during a fishing expedition. One of these creatures that was the offspring of Loki grew large enough to encircle the earth. For ten points, Jormungandr is the “world” version of what type of creature?

Following this conflict, the losing side changed the name of one of its provinces to “Presidente Hayes” to thank Hayes for his resolving of a boundary dispute. During this conflict, the fortress of Humaita was captured by troops under the command of the Duke of Caxias. This war, which began with the invasion of (*) Mato Grosso, ended after the president of its losing side was executed following the Battle of Cerro Cora. That participant in this conflict saw approximately 90% of its male population perish during it. For ten points, name this war in which Francisco Solano Lopez’s Paraguay lost to the namesake coalition of Uruguay, Brazil, and Argentina.
tossups.answer: War of the Triple Alliance [accept Paraguayan War until “Paraguay” is mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: War of the Triple Alliance [accept Paraguayan War until “Paraguay” is mentioned]

tossups.question: They’re not semiconductors, but the Czochralski [choke-RAL-ski] method is used to produce these materials. The Weiss parameters were used to notate the planes occupied by these materials before being replaced by Miller indices. These materials were sorted into 14 different types by Auguste Bravais. A technique applied to these materials observes the diffraction of (*) x-rays, which are predicted using Bragg’s law. These materials may be classified as primitive, body-centered, or face-centered cubic. These materials possess long-range order, unlike amorphous solids. For ten points, name these solids whose structures consist of a namesake lattice and are exemplified by diamond.
tossups.answer: crystals [or crystalline solids; accept semiconductor crystals or x-ray crystallography; prompt on unit cell with “unit cell of what materials?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: crystals [or crystalline solids; accept semiconductor crystals or x-ray crystallography; prompt on unit cell with “unit cell of what materials?”]
promptable: unit cell with “unit cell of what materials?”

bonuses.leadin: A character with these features is found lying face down in mud at a courtyard. For ten points each:
answers: wings [accept “A Very Old Man With Enormous Wings”]
parts: Name these “enormous” features of an elderly character who is briefly locked up in a chicken coop by Pelisayo and Elisenda because he is thought to be a religious figure in one short story.
“A Very Old Man with Enormous Wings” is a short story in Leaf Storm, which is by this Colombian author of One Hundred Years of Solitude.
Leaf Storm and One Hundred Years of Solitude both take place in this fictional Colombian town founded by the Buendia family.
answers_formatted: wings [accept “A Very Old Man With Enormous Wings”]
acceptable: “A Very Old Man With Enormous Wings”

bonuses.leadin: Senator Rand Paul introduced a bill titled “Justice for [this woman]”, which would prohibit the use of no-knock warrants for law enforcement agencies. For ten points each:
parts: Name this woman who was fatally shot by Louisville Metro Police officers in her apartment. On September 15, the city of Louisville settled to pay $12 million to this woman’s family.

In response to Taylor’s murder, this California congresswoman and longtime police reform advocate helped draft the Justice in Policing Act of 2020. This politician was considered to be a potential running mate for Joe Biden before he eventually picked Kamala Harris.

This activist slammed the “white supremacist institution of policing” following the grand jury decision to exonerate all but one officer involved in Taylor’s murder. Many athletes have taken this activist’s lead in kneeling during the national anthem.

bonuses.leadin: A section of this work plays Offenbach’s “Can-Can” at an extremely slow tempo to depict tortoises. For ten points each:
answers: The Carnival of the Animals [or Le carnaval des animaux]
double bass [or string bass or upright bass or contrabass; do not accept or prompt on “contrabassoon”]
parts: Name this musical suite by Camille Saint-Saëns. This suite’s thirteenth section, written for solo cello, is titled “The Swan.”

The eleventh section of The Carnival of the Animals mocks the “Pianists” for clumsily playing these musical sequences of notes. Common types of these musical entities can be major, minor, or pentatonic.

In the work’s fifth section, “The Elephant,” high-pitched themes written by Felix Mendelssohn and Hector Berlioz are ironically played by this instrument. This instrument plays a D minor transcription of “Frère Jacques” at the opening of the third movement of Gustav Mahler’s first symphony.
answers_formatted: The Carnival of the Animals [or Le carnaval des animaux]
double bass [or string bass or upright bass or contrabass; do not accept or prompt on "“contrabassoon”"]

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about scalar bosons:
answers: Higgs boson [accept Peter Higgs; prompt on H0 [h-zero] or God particle]
mesons [accept pi meson or K meson]
parts: Scalar bosons are defined as having a value of zero for this quantity, which has integer values for bosons in general. This quantity measures the intrinsic angular momentum of a particle and is either “up” or “down” for electrons.
This elementary particle is the only boson in the Standard model to have zero spin. The discovery of this particle in 2012 led to the Nobel Prize in Physics being awarded to its British namesake.

This class of particles can be designated as “scalar” or “pseudoscalar” depending on their parity, in addition to having zero spin. These particles are formed from quark-antiquark pairs, and include the pion and kaon.

bonuses.leadin: After Jose Sanjurjo died in a plane crash, this man’s connections with Hitler and Mussolini allowed him to become Generalísimo and Head of State. For ten points each:
answers: The Soviet Union [or USSR; do not accept or prompt on “Russia”]
parts: Name this man, who served as dictator of Spain after winning the Spanish Civil War.
Though he kept Spain neutral during World War II, Franco sent the Blue Division to fight for Nazi Germany aginst this Stalin-led country, where they fought at the Seige of Leningrad.

While the United States eventually aided Franco due to his anti-communist stance, during the war many volunteers fought against him, including this unit which integrated more than a decade before the U.S. Army.
answers_formatted: The Soviet Union [or USSR; do not accept or prompt on "“Russia”"]

bonuses.leadin: One member of this group rapped about “slave masters posing on your dollar” on the song “JU$T.” For ten points each:
answers: Kendrick Lamar Duckworth [accept any underlined portion; accept Kung fu Kenny or Cornrow Kenny or K.Dot]
parts: Name this Hip-Hop duo composed of El-P and Killer Mike, who released their fourth self-titled album in June 2020.

This man said that “When Hip-Hop was about rappin’… then Killer Mike’d be platinum” on “Hood Politics,” a song from his album To Pimp a Butterfly. His album DAMN. contains the hit singles HUMBLE. and DNA.
Killer Mike was mentored by Big Boi, who forms this other duo with Andre 3000. This group recorded the singles “Ms. Jackson” and “Hey Ya!”
answers_formatted: Kendrick Lamar Duckworth [accept any underlined portion; accept Kung fu Kenny or Cornrow Kenny or K.Dot]

bonuses.leadin: This law was first stated in 1834 by Émile Clapeyron as a combination of other empirical laws. For ten points each:
answers: compressibility factor [or compression factor; prompt on Z; do not accept or prompt on “compressibility”]
parts: Name this law that describes a specific state of matter, commonly written as P V equals n R T. This law is a combination of Boyle’s law, Charles’ law, and Avogadro’s law.
This other law, named for a Dutch physicist, is an improvement of the ideal gas law. This equation adds correctional a and b terms that account for intermolecular forces and nonzero particle size.
This value for a substance at its critical point is three eighths according to the van der Waals equation. For an ideal gas, this value is defined to be equal to one.
answers_formatted: compressibility factor [or compression factor; prompt on Z; do not accept or prompt on "“compressibility”"]

bonuses.leadin: A former participant in this activity drowns in a lake after trying to follow Tito on a swim. For ten points each:
answers: the Glass Bead Game [or Das Glasperlenspiel]
parts: Name this activity practiced by Joseph Knecht, who rises to the position of Magister Ludi in it before leaving Castalia.
This German author wrote about Knecht in his novel The Glass Bead Game. He wrote about Harry Haller in Steppenwolf.
Another Hesse novel follows Goldmund and Narcissus, a man with this profession. In medieval times, many people with this religious profession created illuminated manuscripts.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about the history of socialism in Latin America:
answers: [10] This founder of the Movement for Socialism rose to prominence after leading a trade union of cocaleros. In 2020, this man’s ally Luis Arce was elected president of his home country. ANSWER: Juan Evo Morales Ayma
American embassies [accept Japanese embassies; prompt on diplomatic buildings]
parts: This founder of the Movement for Socialism rose to prominence after leading a trade union of cocaleros. In 2020, this man’s ally Luis Arce was elected president of his home country.

Fidel Castro, the former President of this country, overthrew the dictator Fulgencio Batista in 1959. This country, the namesake of a 1962 Missile Crisis, is currently governed by Raul Castro from Havana.

The Shining Path, a Peruvian Maoist group, was blamed for an attack on one of these buildings in 1993. The Iran Hostage Crisis began when a group of Iranian students took over one of these buildings in Tehran.

bonuses.leadin: Whether it’s barricades or collapsed chandeliers, this European city has been the setting for many occurrences in musical theater. For ten points each:
parts: Jean Valjean carries Marius Pontmercy through its sewers and Eponine sings “On My Own” while wandering the streets of this French capital at night in Les Misérables.

In this Andrew Lloyd Webber musical set in Paris, the deformed title character tutors Christine Daaé in singing in his subterranean lair before she leaves him for Raoul. The title character of this musical supposedly haunts the Palais Garnier.

The creation of the Statue of Liberty in Paris was depicted in Miss Liberty, a musical with a story by Robert Sherwood and music by this songwriter. This lyricist also wrote “God Bless America” and “White Christmas.”

bonuses.leadin: A poem by this man says “The tree of man was never quiet” while describing “woods in riot.” For ten points each:
answers: Andrew Marvell [the poem not named is “To His Coy Mistress”]
parts: Name this author of “On Wenlock Edge” who described the title plant “wearing white for Eastertide” in his poem “Loveliest of trees, the cherry now.”
This other poet described a tree that “grew both day and night / Till it bore an apple bright” in his poem “A Poison Tree.” He’s better known for poems like “The Lamb” and “The Tyger.”

This poet wrote about “Fair trees!” in a poem about “this lovely green;” that poem is “The Garden.” On the theme of vegetation, he wrote about his “vegetable love” in another poem, which begins “had we but world enough and time.”
answers_formatted: Andrew Marvell [the poem not named is “To His Coy Mistress”]

bonuses.leadin: Adenlyl cyclase uses this molecule to synthesize a secondary messenger in signal transduction pathways. For ten points each:
parts: Name this molecule often called the “energy currency” of the cell. The synthesis of this compound is primarily facilitated by cellular respiration.

During oxidative phosphorylation, ATP is synthesized through chemiosmosis and this process, which occurs in the inner mitochondrial membrane. This process results in the reduction of NAD+ [N-A-D-plus] to NADH [N-A-D-H].
In the electron transport chain, electrons are transferred between complexes III and IV via this protein. The release of this protein from the mitochondria activates apoptosis in cells.

bonuses.leadin: This god became bald after trying to store beans under a hat. For ten points each:
answers: stories [accept reasonable equivalents such as tales]
parts: Name this spider god from Akan mythology. This man completed a series of challenges in which he had to capture Onini the Python, the Mmoboro Hornets, Osebo the Leopard, and the fairy Mmoatia.
Anansi completed the challenges detailed above in order to become the god of these things, which recount fictional events.
Anansi received control of all stories from this god, the omniscient and omnipotent sky god of Akan mythology.

bonuses.leadin: A collection of this type of artwork includes pieces titled Pierrot’s Funeral and The Nightmare of the White Elephant. For ten points each:
answers: hats [accept Woman with a Hat or Femme au chapeau]
parts: Identify this style of artwork collected in the book Jazz. Another work in this style is The Swimming Pool, which is housed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

This French artist and co-founder of Fauvism, created several collages for his book Jazz in the later stages of his life. This artist featured five red figures linking arms and playing instruments against a green-and-blue background in his paintings La Musique and La Danse.

A Matisse painting depicting a woman wearing this kind of accessory led to Louis Vauxcelles [voh-cell] coining the name “Fauvism.” In the painting, this accessory is topped with fruit, though it also comes in “bowler” and “top” varieties.
answers_formatted: hats [accept Woman with a Hat or Femme au chapeau]

bonuses.leadin: The Sea Venture was wrecked while trying to deliver supplies to this settlement in 1609. For ten points each:
answers: Thomas West, Baron De La Warr [accept Lord Delaware]
parts: Name this early settlement of the Virginia Colony. During the winter of 1609, this colony faced a period of struggle known as the “Starving Time.”
This body was the elected portion of the Virginia General Assembly, the legislative body of colonial Virginia.
The Starving Time was ended by the arrival of three ships under the command of this man in April 1610. This man also lends his name for an alternate name of the Lenni Lenape people.
answers_formatted: Thomas West, Baron De La Warr [accept Lord Delaware]
acceptable: Thomas West, Baron De La Warr

bonuses.leadin: Shake it down to New Orleans! For ten points, answer the following about literature from the Big Easy:
answers: movies [accept The Moviegoer or equivalent answers such as films]
parts: In this play by Tennessee Williams, Blanche DuBois comes to live with her sister Stella and her abusive husband Stanley in New Orleans after the loss of their family plantation.
This picaresque novel by John Kennedy Toole follows the shenanigans of the corpulent Ignatius J. Reilly in New Orleans.

Walker Percy, another New Orleans author, wrote a novel whose title describes Binx Bolling as a person who goes to these things. Marlon Brando starred in an adaptation of A Streetcar Named Desire in this medium that was directed by Elia Kazan.
answers_formatted: movies [accept The Moviegoer or equivalent answers such as films]

bonuses.leadin: This thinker posited her “theory of difference” and contributed to the development of the Third World and postcolonial feminist movements in her essay collection, Sister Outsider. For ten points each:
answers: Washington, District of Columbia [accept either underlined portion]
Soviet Union [or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; accept Russia or Notes from a Trip to Russia]
parts: Name this 20th century American thinker who reclaimed her Caribbean heritage in her autobiography, Zami: A New Spelling of My Name.

In Zami: A New Spelling of My Name, Lorde recounts her family being denied service at an ice cream parlor in this city. On that trip to this capital city, Lorde recounts walking down Pennsylvania Avenue and seeing the Lincoln Memorial.

In Sister Outsider, Lorde published an essay titled “Notes from a Trip to” this country, which she visited in 1976 to observe a conference hosted by a writers’ union in this country. A thinker from this country wrote the pamphlet What Is to Be Done?
answers_formatted: Soviet Union [or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; accept Russia or Notes from a Trip to Russia]
acceptable: Notes from a Trip to Russia

bonuses.leadin: The modulus of these numbers is geometrically represented by the distance between a point and the origin of their namesake plane. For ten points each:
answers: Augustin-Louis Cauchy [KOH-shee] [accept Cauchy integral formula or Cauchy residue theorem]
parts: Name these numbers that are commonly written as the sum of a real component and an imaginary component. The real numbers and imaginary numbers are a subset of these numbers.

For a given complex number, this related value is geometrically determined by reflection over the x-axis of the complex plane. Multiplying a complex number by this value gives the square of the modulus.
A field of analysis named for complex numbers was pioneered by this French mathematician. In complex analysis, this mathematician names an integral formula and the residue theorem.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer some questions about the New Kingdom pharaoh Hatshepsut:
parts: Hatshepsut sent an expedition to this southern land in order to reopen trade routes. Her emissaries brought back frankincense and myrrh, leading to what may have been the first recorded tree transplantation.

Hatshepsut had a temple complex at Deir el-Bahri built to serve as one of these buildings. The much earlier pyramids of Giza may have also served as these buildings for pharaohs, similar to a modern cemetery.

In order to make herself seem more legitimate and masculine, Hatshepsut ordered that these attributes be added to her official portraits. Most pharaohs wore features of this kind made of goat hair as a sign of royalty.

bonuses.leadin: In Baha’i faith, this practice occurs for 19 days during daylight hours in March. For ten points each:
parts: Name this practice which involves abstaining from eating or drinking. This practice is the responsibility of the individual in the Baha'i faith.

The prophet of Baha'i faith, Baha'u'llah, spent his later years in one of these places in Ridvan. A biblical one of these places is guarded by a flaming sword, and Mormons believe that place is located in Jackson County, Missouri.

A ten year crusade led by the Guardian of the Faith, Shoghi Effendi, led to the establishment of this governing institution of the faith in Haifa, Israel. This body has nine members that are elected every five years
